state.description: This is where you might entertain friends...if you had any. You see a comfy albeit slightly moldy arm chair facing the fireplace, your phone atop a spindly table, and a bookcase full of books you’ve skimmed. In front of you, there is the front door, behind you is the way to the kitchen, and to your left is the staircase leading to the second floor.

This is where you might entertain friends...if you had any. The room is dimly lit by a lamp and the weak, jittering light of the fireplace. state.description: Now it's in front of the door!

state.description: Your painting of a man with an entire dog protruding from his stomach. You bought this from some grubby looking guys at a garage sale; apparently they were trying to sell everything from their failed game company.
state.get: Maybe later. Like, in a few years.

A shitty, spindly table. You know there is a mostly empty address book in its single drawer.

This is where you push food into your mouth, sometimes after cooking it. Stains and spills dot the floor, walls, and surfaces. In the center of the room is a counter where you usually prepare your food. On it rests a toaster, a blender, and a knife block. Standard kitchen appliances fill the room, like your refrigerator, sink, and a stovetop/oven. There is a door to the living room and a door leading to the back yard.

A plain, white, food-cooling box. A smiley-face magnet pins an “A+” math test to the front.

It looks like a boob.

Jerome Freeman was pretty good at math. Bummer he’s not here to help you.

state.description: Bread goes in, toast comes out. You could call it magic, but you would be wrong. You’re often wrong.
state.get: You bash the toaster against the counter, separating it into many pieces. None of them seem particularly useful except for the spring, which you pocket.

state.description: Rest in pieces.
state.get: I think you already grabbed the useful bits.

state.description: Most recently used for impromptu bartending. Residue of Mountain Dew and Malibu covers the inside.

For lighting stuff, ya know?

A poster for the blockbuster hit, “Glory in his bosom,” that you enjoyed so. An epic tale in the saga of brave Johnny Knifeblaster. You recall one scene that drew your interest; KB used his cunning knowledge of explosives to make a small bomb out of gasoline and orange juice.
state.get: No point in taking this down. In fact, it would be tantamount to heresy for this poster to not be displayed with pride at all times.

state.description: The low light of the basement reveals piled boxes, a tool bench, and the washer and dryer. For a moment you have an insane desire to grab your clothes out of the dryer and start acting as though nothing is wrong.

Well, okay. You spread ignition fluid over the logs, glancing back to the front door while your heart races. You duck your head and climb into the soot-covered hole, balancing yourself delicately on the logs. As you strike the match, you briefly see the blackened bricks around you before you drop the match to your feet. As you burn, you grimly think, “at least I died on my own terms.”
Buddy, you couldn't climb a rope, let alone that fence.
You swill the bleach. Hmm, tastes like poison!”

You drop trou’ and get to work. After a minute of straining you stand back and take a moment to admire your artistry. Disgusting hog that you are, you hobble away without wiping, pants still around your ankles.

What do you want to use it with?
You open the front door, but you die! OH NO!

The phone rings just once before a gruff, loud voice barks “Paulie’s Pizza, whaddya want?” “Paulie, it’s me, I need help!”, you hurriedly exclaim. Paulie, recognizing your voice immediately, says, “Oh, it’s you. Your usual will be there in 30 minutes,” before hanging up. Great! Maybe now you can die with a full stomach at least.
IT'S MRS. JONES
When the line connects, all that can be heard is a single, unbroken, bloodcurdling scream. Man, you can always count on Phil.

The phone rings once or twice and a curt woman answers, “9-1-1, what’s your emergency?” You quickly explain that a maniac is trying to break into your home and murder you. The operator is taken aback for a moment, but calmly tells you, “Remain in your home, officers will be there in 20 minutes.”
You hear some wacky stuff. Something something tentacles.
You open the drawer.
You close the drawer.
You open the fridge.
You close the fridge.
You open the freezer.
You close the freezer.
You open the cabinet.
You close the cabinet.
You open the closet.
You close the closet.
You move the arm chair.
Spooky spooky tentacles
As you tilt the book to grab it, THE PASSAGE OPENS WOO WOO WOO!
“Sometimes, estate owners will install switches that look like books.” The rest of the pages are blank. Man, if only this book gave real, actionable advice, huh?

You page through frantically, in the vain hope that you’ll find something to help you. Your eye catches a page with a diagram demonstrating how to make a bear trap using household items. It says you would need something sharp, like a knife, and a springing mechanism.
Book 4!
It's already on!
If you turned it off you wouldn’t be able to see anything, and probably get killed. You decide to leave it on.
You open the curtain.
You close the curtain.
You open the cabinet.
You close the cabinet.
You scurry into the shower like a trapped rat.
You scurry into the closet like a trapped rat.
You scurry under the bed like a trapped rat.
It's already open!
I think it's good how it is.
no!
You open the back door.
You close the back door.
You open the oven.
You close the oven.
You use the computer
You move the painting, revealing DA SAFE?
You open the drawer.
You close the drawer.
You open the safe.
Safe Combination: 1-2-4-3. Really original, pal.

A metal table covered in various surgical tools and items. Specifically, a scalpel, a pair of scissors, and a spoon.
A metal table covered in various surgical tools and items. Specifically, a scalpel and a pair of scissors.
A window! From here you can see... not much. It’s dark. You can just make out your mailbox at the end of your front lawn. There appears to be someone standing at the door...
